  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" >
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" >
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" >
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2,514,000</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" >
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" >
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" >
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(19,208,000</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" >
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">)</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" >
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="12%" valign="bottom" >
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">5,000</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom" >
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>




<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">For fiscal 2005, the income tax provision was $2,514,000, based on an effective tax rate of 34%, which was based on federal and state statutory rates, reduced by benefits from research and development credits and foreign sales activity.&#160; In fiscal 2004, the income tax benefit totaled $19,208,000, which included a one-time income tax benefit of $19,450,000 related to existing deferred tax assets (principally net operating loss carryforwards) because we concluded that it is more likely than not that these assets will be realized.&#160; Prior to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2004, these deferred tax assets had been fully reserved.&#160; The $19,450,000 income tax benefit is partially offset by a current tax provision of $242,000 related to taxes for various state tax jurisdictions and federal alternative minimum tax for fiscal 2004.&#160; For fiscal 2003, the income tax expense totaled $5,000, which primarily related to taxes for various state tax
jurisdictions.&#160; We expect our effective tax rate will be approximately 36% for federal and various state tax jurisdictions in the near term.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In October 2003, under the terms of our respective Certificates of Determination with respect to both the Series D Preferred Stock and Series E Preferred Stock, all outstanding shares of the Series D Preferred and the Series E Preferred automatically converted into shares of common stock after twenty consecutive trading days where the per share closing price of our common stock as reported on the Nasdaq National Market exceeded $14.00 and $12.00, respectively.&#160; Consequently, we have eliminated our obligation to pay an ongoing annual dividend to the holders of the Series D Preferred and Series E Preferred. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Liquidity and Capital Resources</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of March 31, 2005, we had $22,634,000 in cash, cash equivalents and short-term investments as compared to $17,322,000 at March 31, 2004.&#160; </font></p>

  <td width="2%" valign="bottom" >

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Operating Activities</b> - During the fiscal year ended March 31, 2005, we generated $6,321,000 of cash from operating activities compared to $7,198,000 for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2004.&#160; This change was primarily the result of net income of $4,851,000 adjusted for the effects of non-cash expenses including depreciation and amortization of $1,896,000, stock option income tax benefits of $608,000, an increase in current net deferred tax assets of $4,068,000 and a decrease in non-current net deferred tax assets of $5,592,000.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Trade Receivables - Our gross trade receivable balance was $10,991,000 and $8,459,000 as of March 31, 2005 and March 31, 2004, respectively.&#160; The increase in our trade receivable balance was primarily due to a higher increase in sales in the last month of the fourth quarter of fiscal 2005 as compared to fiscal 2004. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Inventories - Inventories increased to $8,355,000 as of March 31, 2005 from $5,736,000 as of March 31, 2004, primarily related to purchases due to a higher projected sales volume.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Current Net Deferred Tax Assets - Current net deferred tax assets increased to $4,677,000 as of March 31, 2005 from $609,000 as of March 31, 2004, as a result of anticipated utilization of net operating losses on projected income for fiscal 2006.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Non-current Net Deferred Tax Assets - Non-current net deferred tax assets decreased to $15,032,000 as of March 31, 2005 from $20,624,000 as of March 31, 2004, as a result of utilization of net operating loss carryforwards in fiscal 2005 and anticipated utilization of net operating losses for fiscal 2006.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Accounts Payable - Accounts payable increased to $3,850,000 as of March 31, 2005 from $2,721,000 as of March 31, 2004, related to inventory purchases due to a higher projected sales volume.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Accrued Payroll and Related Expenses - Accrued payroll and related expenses decreased to $1,867,000 as of March 31, 2005 from $2,853,000 as of March 31, 2004, due to a reduction in accrued bonus at March 31, 2005 since qualifiers for bonus payments were not met in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Other Accrued Liabilities - Other accrued liabilities increased to $828,000 as of March 31, 2005 from $319,000 as of March 31, 2004, related to an increase in income taxes payable and other accrued expenses related to professional services.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Deferred Revenue - The current portion of deferred revenue increased to $907,000 as of March 31, 2005 from $264,000 as of March 31, 2004 and the non-current portion of deferred revenue increased to $1,146,000 as of March 31, 2005 from $474,000 as of March 31, 2004, as a result of incentives in the form of free goods given to customers.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net cash provided by operating activities in fiscal 2004 was $7,198,000.&#160; This was primarily the result of net income of $24,033,000 offset by the effects of non-cash expenses including depreciation and amortization of $1,708,000, common stock issued for employee benefits plan of $73,000, stock-based compensation of $24,000, stock option income tax benefits of $1,902,000 and an increase in total net deferred tax assets of $21,233,000.&#160; Additional cash was generated from a decrease of $355,000 in prepaid expenses, deposits and other assets; increases of $637,000 in accounts payable; $1,042,000 in accrued payroll and related expenses; $88,000 in deferred rent; and $42,000 in deferred revenue.&#160; Uses of cash from operating activities included increases totaling $1,437,000 in trade receivables and inventories; and a decrease of long-term commission obligation of $36,000.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net income in fiscal 2004 included a one-time income tax benefit of $19,450,000 related to existing deferred tax assets (principally net operating loss carryforwards) because we concluded that it is more likely than not that these assets will be realized.&#160; Prior to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2004, the net deferred tax assets had been fully reserved.&#160; The increase in trade receivable of $720,000 is primarily due to sales made in the last month of the fourth quarter of fiscal 2004.&#160; The increase in inventory of $717,000, which mainly consists of finished reagent discs, is primarily due to higher sales forecast.&#160; </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">22</font></p>
<hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We anticipate that we will incur incremental additional costs to support our future operations, including further commercialization of our products and development of new test methods that will allow us to expand our veterinary market and further penetrate the human medical market; additional pre-clinical testing and clinical trials for our current and future products;  acquisition of capital equipment for our manufacturing facility, which includes the ongoing costs related to continuing development of our current and future products; and research and design costs related to the continuing development of our current and future products. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We anticipate that our existing capital resources, available line of credit and anticipated revenue from the sales of our products will be adequate to satisfy our currently planned operating and financial requirements through at least the next twelve months.&#160; Our future capital requirements will largely depend upon the increased market acceptance of our point-of-care blood analyzer products.&#160; However, our sales for any future periods are not predictable with a significant degree of certainty.&#160; Regardless, we may seek to raise additional funds to leverage our internal expansion into the human medical market or pursue strategic acquisition opportunities.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Investing Activities</b>&nbsp;- Net cash used in investing activities for fiscal 2005 was $11,344,000.&#160; The cash  used in fiscal 2005 was primarily due to purchases of $16,787,000 in short-term investments consisting of corporate obligations, U.S. Treasury and Agency securities and various certificate of deposits offset by the maturities of various certificate of deposits totaling $7,998,000 that were purchased in fiscal 2004.&#160; Cash used in investing activities also included purchases of property and equipment of $2,562,000, primarily to support both our increased product demand and our goal of more efficient production lines, as well as our new product introduction.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net cash used in investing activities for fiscal 2004 was $10,029,000.&#160; This primarily included purchases of $7,998,000 in short-term investments consisting of various certificate of deposits.&#160; Cash used in investing activities also included purchases of $1,281,000 in property and equipment and $750,000 of intellectual property relating to patents.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We anticipate that we will continue to purchase property and equipment necessary in the normal course of our business.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Financing Activities</b> - Net cash provided by financing activities in fiscal 2005 was $1,475,000, which primarily consisted of proceeds from the exercise of stock options of $810,000 and warrants of $687,000.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net cash provided by financing activities in fiscal 2004 was $1,725,000, which included $2,716,000 of proceeds from the exercise of stock options and warrants, offset by repayments of $991,000 on our equipment financing loan and capital leases.&#160; In March 2004, we paid off the outstanding balance of our equipment financing loan of $933,000.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Preferred Stock</b> - In October 2003, under the terms of our respective Certificate of Determination with respect to both the Series D Preferred Stock (the &#147;Series D Preferred&#148;) and Series E Preferred Stock (the &#147;Series E Preferred&#148;), the Series D Preferred and the Series E Preferred automatically converted into shares of common stock after twenty consecutive trading days where the per share closing price of our common stock as reported on the Nasdaq National Market exceeded $14.00 and $12.00, respectively.&#160; Elective conversions, coupled with the automatic conversion of all remaining outstanding Series E Preferred Stock, resulted in the conversion of 5,570 shares of Series E Preferred Stock into 856,907 shares of common stock during fiscal 2004.&#160; Elective conversions, coupled with the automatic conversion of all remaining outstanding Series D Preferred Stock, resulted in the conversion of 6,508 shares of Series D Preferred Stock
into 929,699 shares of common stock during fiscal 2004.&#160; Consequently, we have eliminated our obligation to pay an ongoing annual dividend that the holders of the Series D Preferred and Series E Preferred would have otherwise received in either cash or shares of our common stock.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Line of Credit </b>- We have established a line of credit with Comerica Bank-California which provides for borrowings of up to $2,000,000.&#160; The line of credit terminates upon notification by either party and the outstanding balance is payable upon demand.&#160; The line of credit bears interest at the bank&#146;s prime rate minus 0.25%, which totaled 5.50% at March 31, 2005, and is payable monthly.&#160; Of the $2,000,000 available, $410,000 was committed to secure a letter of credit for our facilities lease at March 31, 2005.&#160; At March 31, 2005, there was no amount outstanding under our line of credit.&#160; The weighted average interest rate on the line of credit during fiscal 2005 and 2004 was 4.45% and 3.92%, respectively. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The line of credit agreement contains certain financial covenants, which are evaluated on a quarterly basis.&#160; Included in these financial covenants, among other stipulations, is a requirement that we have a minimum net income of $25,000 before preferred stock dividends and accretion in any three quarters of a fiscal year, provided that any loss before preferred stock dividends and accretion on preferred stock incurred in the remaining quarter is not to exceed $250,000.&#160; We are also required to be profitable, as defined, on a fiscal year to date basis beginning with the six month period ended September 30, 2004 and to have net income before preferred stock dividends and accretion on preferred stock of $1,150,000 for the fiscal year ended March 31, 2005.&#160; In addition, we are required to have a quick ratio, as defined, of not less than 2.00 to 1.00, cash flow coverage, as defined, of not less than 1.25 to 1.00, debt to net worth ratio, as defined,
not greater than 1.00 to 1.00 and to maintain a tangible effective net worth, as defined, of not less than $25,731,000.&#160; At March 31, 2005, we were in compliance with these covenants.</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">23</font></p>
<hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Borrowings under the line of credit are collateralized by our net book value of assets of $61.7 million at March 31, 2005 including our intellectual property.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Critical Accounting Policies</b> - We have identified the policies below as critical to our business operations and the understanding of our results of operations.&#160; The impact and any associated risks related to these policies on our business operations are discussed below.&#160; For a more detailed discussion on the application of these and other accounting policies, see the Notes to Financial Statements included in this Annual Report on Form 10-K.&#160; The preparation of financial statements in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States of America requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the date of the financial statements and the reported amounts of revenues and expenses during the reporting period.&#160; There can be no assurance that actual results will not differ from those
estimates.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Revenue Recognition</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Revenues from product sales, net of estimated sales allowances and rebates, are recognized upon shipment when a purchase order has been received, the sales price is fixed and determinable and collection of the resulting receivable is reasonably assured.&#160; The Company periodically provides incentives in the form of free goods to customers in connection with the sale of its products.&#160; Revenue from such sales is allocated separately to the instruments and free goods based on the relative fair value of each element.&#160; Revenue allocated to free goods is deferred until the goods are shipped to the customer.&#160; Rights of return are not provided and provisions are made at the time the related revenue is recognized for the estimated future costs to be incurred under initial standard warranty obligations of one year.&#160; Revenues received for, or allocated to extended warranty arrangements are recognized ratably over the related warranty period.&#160;
Instrument revenues under cross-distribution agreements (where we and another party purchase each other&#146;s products for resale) are recognized upon sale of the products to the end user.&#160; Development and licensing revenue is recognized in accordance with the related contract terms.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We make estimates to adjust revenues for estimated sales allowances and rebates based on historical data and terms of current promotions, including cash rebates and trade-in programs in which we issue credit to customers as incentives for purchasing our products.&#160; Although we believe these estimates are reliable, it is possible that actual allowance or rebate amounts realized could vary from our estimates and that the amounts of such differences could affect our operating results.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Reserves and Accruals</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We maintain allowances for doubtful accounts based on our assessment of the collectibility of amounts owed us by customers which is mostly determined by the customer&#146;s payment history and the outstanding period of accounts.&#160; In addition, we provide provisions for the estimated future costs to be incurred under our standard warranty obligations of one year.&#160; Actual amounts realized could vary from our estimates and affect our operating results.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Income Taxes</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of March 31, 2005, we had net deferred tax assets of $19,709,000 primarily resulting from net operating loss carryforwards (&#147;NOLs&#148;), which consist of $43,373,000 of federal NOLs that expire at various dates from fiscal years 2006 through 2021, and $6,677,000 of California NOLs that expire at various dates from fiscal years 2006 through 2011.&#160; At March 31, 2005, the Company maintained a valuation allowance of $678,000 relating to federal research and development tax credits which expire in fiscal years 2006 through 2008.&#160; We will continue to evaluate our deferred tax assets in the future to determine whether a deferred tax asset valuation allowance is required at some future point.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Contractual Obligations</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of March 31, 2005, we have the following outstanding contractual obligations:</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At March 31, 2005, there was no outstanding balance on our line of credit with Comerica Bank-California.&#160; The line of credit terminates upon notification by either party and the outstanding balance is payable upon demand.&#160;&#160; In connection with our facility lease agreement, we have established a letter of credit for $410,000, which is secured by our line of credit.&#160; </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">24</font></p>
<hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>
<p>

<tr bgcolor="#e6e6e6">
  <td  valign="bottom" >
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Present   value of minimum lease payments</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom" >
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom" >

  <td  valign="bottom" >
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">16,000</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom" >
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Purchase Commitments</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In November 2003, we entered into an OEM agreement with Diatron Messtechnik GmbH (DIATRON) of Austria to purchase DIATRON hematology instruments.&#160; Under the terms of the agreement, we are committed to purchase a minimum number of hematology units from DIATRON once the product was qualified for sale.&#160; Qualification occurred in May 2004 and accordingly, we have minimum purchase commitments.&#160; As of March 31, 2005, the outstanding commitment for fiscal 2006 through 2009 was $1,461,000, $2,791,000, $2,792,000 and $2,792,000, respectively.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Contingencies</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We are from time to time involved in various litigation matters in the normal course of business.&#160; While the outcome of these proceedings and claims cannot be predicted with certainty, we believe that the ultimate resolution of these matters will not have a material effect on our financial position or results of operations.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Recent Accounting Pronouncements</b> - </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Financial Accounting Standards Board (&#147;FASB&#148;) issued Interpretation No. 46 (&#147;FIN 46&#148;), &#147;Consolidation of Variable Interest Entities,&#148; in January 2003, and a revised interpretation of FIN 46 (&#147;FIN 46-R&#148;) in December 2003.&#160; FIN 46 requires certain variable interest entities (&#147;VIEs&#148;) to be consolidated by the primary beneficiary of the entity if the equity investors in the entity do not have the characteristics of a controlling financial interest or do not have sufficient equity at risk for the entity to finance its activities without additional subordinated financial support from other parties.&#160; The provisions of FIN 46 are effective immediately for all arrangements entered into after January 31, 2003.&#160; Since January 31, 2003, we have not invested in any entities that we believe are variable interest entities for which we are the primary beneficiary.&#160; The adoption of FIN 46-R in the first
quarter of fiscal 2005 did not have an impact our financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company accounts for stock-based compensation awards issued to employees using the intrinsic value measurement provisions of Accounting Principles Board Opinion No. 25, Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees (Opinion 25).&#160; Accordingly, no compensation expense has been recorded for stock options granted with exercise prices greater than or equal to the fair value of the underlying common stock at the option grant date.&#160; On December 16, 2004, the Financial Accounting Standards Board issued Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 123 (revised 2004), Share-Based Payment (&#147;SFAS 123R&#148;).&#160; SFAS 123R eliminates the alternative of applying the intrinsic value measurement provisions of Opinion 25 to stock compensation awards issued to employees.&#160; Rather, the new standard requires enterprises to measure the cost of employee services received in exchange for an award of equity instruments based on the grant-date fair value of the
award.&#160; That cost will be recognized over the period during which an employee is required to provide services in exchange for the award, known as the requisite service period (usually the vesting period).</font></p>

<p  align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">25</font></p>
<hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has not yet quantified the effects of the adoption of SFAS 123R, but it is expected that the new standard may result in significant stock-based compensation expense.&#160; The pro forma effects on net income and earnings per share if we had applied the fair value recognition provisions of the original SFAS 123 on stock compensation awards (rather than applying the intrinsic value measurement provisions of Opinion 25) are disclosed in Note 1 to the Financial Statements.&#160; Although such pro forma effects of applying the original SFAS 123 may be indicative of the effects of adopting SFAS 123R, the provisions of these two statements differ in some important respects.&#160; The actual effects of adopting SFAS 123R will be dependent on numerous factors including, but not limited to, the valuation model we choose to value stock-based awards; the assumed award forfeiture rate; the accounting policies adopted concerning the method of recognizing the fair value of



awards over the requisite service period; and the transition method (as described below) chosen for adopting SFAS 123R.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">SFAS 123R will be effective for our first quarter of fiscal 2007, which begins April 1, 2006, and requires the use of the Modified Prospective Application Method.&#160; Under this method SFAS 123R is applied to new awards and to awards modified, repurchased, or cancelled after the effective date.&#160; Additionally, compensation cost for the portion of awards for which the requisite service has not been rendered (such as unvested options) that are outstanding as of the date of adoption shall be recognized as the remaining requisite services are rendered.&#160; The compensation cost relating to unvested awards at the date of adoption shall be based on the grant-date fair value of those awards as calculated for pro forma disclosures under the original SFAS 123.&#160; In addition, companies may use the Modified Retrospective Application Method.&#160; This method may be applied to all prior years for which the original SFAS 123 was effective or only to prior interim
periods in the year of initial adoption.&#160; If the Modified Retrospective Application Method is applied, financial statements for prior periods shall be adjusted to give effect to the fair-value-based method of accounting for awards on a consistent basis with the pro forma disclosures required for those periods under the original SFAS 123.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In March 2004, the EITF reached a final consensus on Issue 03-01, &#147;The Meaning of Other-Than-Temporary Impairment and its Application to Certain Investments,&#148; to provide additional guidance in determining whether investment securities have an impairment which should be considered other-than-temporary.&#160; The adoption of Issue 03-01 did not have an effect on operating results or financial condition.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>RISK FACTORS THAT MAY AFFECT OUR PERFORMANCE</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our future performance is subject to a number of risks.&#160; If any of the following risks actually occur, our business could be harmed and the trading price of our common stock could decline. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;When used in these risk factors, the words &#147;anticipates,&#148; &#147;believes,&#148; &#147;expects,&#148; &#147;intends,&#148; &#147;plans,&#148; &#147;future,&#148; and similar expressions identify forward-looking statements.&#160; Our actual results could differ materially from those that we project in the forward-looking statements as a result of factors that we have set forth throughout this document as well as factors of which we are currently not aware. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We Have Not Been Consistently Profitable; We Must Increase Sales Of Our Piccolo And VetScan DXS Products To Maintain Consistent Profitability </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We recognized a net loss attributable to common shareholders in two of the last twelve fiscal quarters ended March 31, 2005.&#160; There can be no assurance that we will experience profitability in the future.&#160; As of March 31, 2005, we have incurred cumulative net losses of $33 million.&#160; Our ability to be consistently profitable will depend, in part, on our ability to increase our sales volumes of our Piccolo and VetScan DXS products.&#160; Increasing the sales volume of our products will depend upon our ability to: </font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We cannot assure you that we will be able to successfully increase our sales volumes of our products to achieve sustained profitability. </font></p>

<p  align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">26</font></p>
<hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We Are Not Able To Predict Sales In Future Quarters And A Number Of Factors Affect Our Periodic Results </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are not able to accurately predict our sales in future quarters.&#160; Our revenue in the veterinary market are derived primarily by selling to distributors who resell our products to the ultimate user.&#160; In December 2004, we terminated our relationship with Vedco, Inc., a warehousing cooperative for member distributors who sold Abaxis products to their respective customers, as part of the realignment of our distribution channel.&#160;During the third and fourth quarters of fiscal 2005, we worked with other U.S. based regional and national distributors, which included American Veterinary Supply Corp., DVM Resources, Henry Schein, IVESCO, TradeWinds Trading Company and Western Medical Supply, to expand their sales and services to support the customers served by other Vedco distributors.&#160; In the third quarter of fiscal 2005, we negotiated direct distributor agreements with Vedco members
Merritt Veterinary Supply and Miller Veterinary Supply.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;While we are better able to predict sales of our reagent discs, as we sell these discs primarily for use with blood chemistry analyzers that we sold in prior periods, we generally are unable to predict with much certainty sales of our analyzers, as we typically sell our analyzers to new users.&#160; Accordingly, our sales in any one quarter are not indicative of our sales in any future period.&#160; In addition, we generally operate with limited order backlog, because we ship our products shortly after we receive the orders from our customers.&#160; As a result, our product sales in any quarter are generally dependent on orders that we receive and ship in that quarter.&#160; We base our expense levels, which are to a large extent fixed, in part on our expectations as to future revenues.&#160; We may be unable to reduce our spending in a timely manner to compensate for any unexpected revenue
shortfall.&#160; As a result, any such shortfall would immediately materially and adversely impact our operating results and financial condition.&#160; In addition, we have historically experienced a decrease in our sales, especially in Europe, in our second and third quarters, ending in September and December of each year, which we believe is due to seasonal patterns in the decision making processes to acquire our products.&#160; Accordingly, we believe that period to period comparisons of our results of operations are not necessarily meaningful.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our periodic operating results have varied in the past.&#160; In the future, we anticipate our periodic operating results to vary significantly depending on, but not limited to, a number of factors, including, in addition to those factors discussed elsewhere in this section: </font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We Could Fail to Achieve Anticipated Revenue If The Market Does Not Accept Our Products</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our core compact blood chemistry analyzer product differs substantially from current blood chemistry analyzers on the market.&#160; Our primary competition is from centralized laboratories that offer a greater number of tests than our products, but do so at a greater cost and requiring more time.&#160; We also compete with other point-of-care analyzers that cost more, require more maintenance and offer a narrower range of tests.&#160; However, these point-of-care analyzers are generally marketed by larger companies which have greater resources for sales and marketing, in addition to a recognized brand name and established distribution relationships. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Historically we have marketed our VetScan analyzer to veterinarians and we have relatively limited experience in large scale sales of our Piccolo analyzer into the human medical market.&#160; We continue to develop new animal blood tests that we cannot be assured will be accepted by the veterinary market.&#160; Although we believe that our blood analyzers offer consumers many advantages, including according to our analyses substantial cost savings, in terms of the actual product and implementation of it procedurally, these advantages involve changes to current standard practices, such as using large clinical laboratories, that will require changes in both the procedures and mindset of care providers.&#160; The human medical market in particular is highly regulated, structured, difficult to penetrate and often slow to adopt new product offerings.&#160; If we are unable to convince large numbers of medical
clinics, hospitals and other point-of-care environments of the benefits of our products, we will suffer lost sales and could fail to achieve anticipated revenue.</font></p>

<p  align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">27</font></p>
<hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We are Dependent Upon Our Profitability, and If We Cannot Remain Profitable We May Need Additional Funding In The Future And These Funds May Not Be Available To Us</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We believe that our existing capital resources, available line of credit and anticipated revenue from the sales of our products will be adequate to satisfy our currently planned operating and financial requirements through March 31, 2006, although no assurances can be given.&#160; The bank financing documents for our available line of credit contain a number of covenants concerning financial tests that we must meet that are more fully detailed in the agreements that we have filed with the SEC as exhibits to our periodic reports.&#160; We may need additional funds if we are unable to meet requirements for continuing access to bank financing or if we do not achieve anticipated revenues from the sale of our Piccolo and VetScan products.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Further, we expect to incur incremental additional costs to support our future operations, including: </font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="2%" valign="top">

  <td width="95%" valign="top">
  <p>

 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">additional pre-clinical testing and clinical trials for   our current and future products.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;To the extent that our existing resources and anticipated revenue from the sale of our products are insufficient to fund our activities or if we are unable to meet the financial tests contained in our bank financing documents, we may have to raise additional funds from the issuance of public or private securities.&#160; In the event that we cannot maintain compliance with the financial covenants of our bank financing agreements, we may also be subject to increased interest rate expenses.&#160; We may not be able to raise additional funding, or if we are able to, we may not be able to raise funding on acceptable terms.&#160; We may also dilute then-existing shareholders if we raise additional funds by issuing new equity securities.&#160; Alternately, we may have to relinquish rights to certain of our technologies, products and/or sales territories if we are required to obtain funds through arrangements
with collaborative partners.&#160; If we are unable to raise needed funds, we may be required to curtail our operations significantly.&#160; This would materially adversely affect our operating results and financial condition.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We Rely On Patents And Other Proprietary Information, The Loss Of Any Of Which Would Negatively Affect Our Business </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As of March 31, 2005, 33 patent applications have been filed on behalf of Abaxis with the United States Patent and Trademark Office, of which 29 have been issued.&#160; Additionally, we have filed several international patent applications covering the same subject matter as our domestic applications.&#160; The patent position of any medical device manufacturer, including Abaxis, is uncertain and may involve complex legal and factual issues.&#160; Consequently, we may not be issued any additional patents, either domestically or internationally.&#160; Furthermore, our patents may not provide significant proprietary protection because there is a chance that they will be circumvented or invalidated.&#160; We cannot be certain that we were the first creator of the inventions covered by our issued patents or pending patent applications, or that we were the first to file patent applications for these inventions,
because (1) the United States Patent and Trademark Office maintains all patent applications that are not filed in any foreign jurisdictions in secrecy until it issues the patents (unless a patent application owner files a request for publication) and (2) publications of discoveries in the scientific or patent literature tend to lag behind actual discoveries by several months.&#160; We may have to participate in interference proceedings, which are proceedings in front of the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office, to determine who will be issued a patent.&#160; These proceedings could be costly and could be decided against us.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We also rely upon copyrights, trademarks and unpatented trade secrets.&#160; Others may independently develop substantially equivalent proprietary information and techniques that would undermine our proprietary technologies.&#160; Further, others may gain access to our trade secrets or disclose such technology.&#160; Although we require our employees, consultants and advisors to execute agreements that require that our corporate information be kept confidential and that any inventions by these individuals are property of Abaxis, there can be no assurance that these agreements will provide meaningful protection or adequate remedies for our trade secrets in the event of unauthorized use or disclosure of such information.&#160; The unauthorized dissemination of our confidential information would negatively impact our business.</font></p>

<p  align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">28</font></p>
<hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We Continue to Develop Our Marketing And Distribution Experience In the Human Diagnostic Market</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Although we have gained experience marketing our VetScan system products in the veterinary diagnostic market, we have much less experience in marketing the Piccolo system in the human diagnostic market.&#160; Accordingly, we have limited sales, marketing and distribution experience, especially in the human diagnostic market.&#160; We cannot assure you that: &#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="2%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="95%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">we will be able to establish and maintain effective   distribution arrangements in the human medical market;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">any distribution arrangements that we are able to   establish will be successful in marketing our products; or</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">the costs associated with marketing and distributing our   products will not be excessive.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Should we fail to effectively develop our marketing and distribution efforts, our growth will be limited and our results of operations will be adversely affected.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We May Inadvertently Produce Defective Products, Which May Subject Us to Significant Warranty Liabilities or Product Liability Claims And We May Have Insufficient Product Liability Insurance</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our business exposes us to potential warranty and product liability risks which are inherent in the testing, manufacturing and marketing of human and veterinary medical products.&#160; We strive to apply sophisticated methods to raw materials and produce defect-free medical test equipment.&#160; Although we have established procedures for quality control on both the raw materials that we receive from suppliers and our manufactured final products, these procedures may prove inadequate to detect a defect that either occurs in limited quantities or that we have not anticipated.&#160; We believe that our Piccolo and VetScan systems detect the vast majority of errors that occur on our reagent discs and automatically reject such tests, prompting the medical provider to retest the patient.&#160; However, our Piccolo and VetScan systems may be unable to detect errors which could result in the misdiagnosis of
human or veterinary patients.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Should we inadvertently ship defective products, we may be subject to substantial claims under our warranty policy or product liability law.&#160; In addition, our policy is to credit medical providers for any defective product that we produce, including those reagent discs that are rejected by our Piccolo and VetScan systems. &#160;Therefore, even if a mass defect within a lot or lots of reagent discs were detected by our Piccolo and VetScan systems, our need to replace such reagent discs free of charge would materially harm our financial condition.&#160; Further, in the event that a product defect is not detected by our Piccolo system, our relatively recent expansion into the human medical market greatly increases the risk that the amount of damages involved with just one product defect would be material to our operations.&#160; We currently maintain limited product liability insurance that we believe
is adequate for our needs, taking into account the risks involved and cost of coverage.&#160; However, our product liability insurance and cash may be insufficient to cover potential liabilities.&#160; In addition, in the future the coverage that we require may be unavailable on commercially reasonable terms, if at all.&#160; Even with our current insurance coverage, a mass product defect, product liability claim or recall would materially adversely affect our business or our financial condition.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Many of Our Sales Force Have Been Employed by Us for Less Than One Year And We Must Effectively Train And Integrate Our Sales Team In Order To Achieve Our Anticipated Revenue</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At March 31, 2005, we had thirty-five full-time sales personnel involved in our sales and marketing activities, many of whom have been employed by us for a limited period of time.&#160; While these individuals work with our distribution partners both domestically and internationally to extend our market reach, the primary selling activities are often done by these individuals.&#160; If we are to increase our sales, we will need to train new salespeople and supervise them closely.&#160; We also will continue hiring additional sales personnel.&#160; If we are unable to retain our existing personnel, or attract and train additional qualified personnel, our growth may be limited due to our lack of capacity to market our products.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We Need to Successfully Manufacture and Market Additional Reagent Discs For The Human Diagnostic Market If We Are To Compete In That Market</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have developed a blood analysis system that consists of a portable blood analyzer and single-use reagent discs.&#160; Each reagent disc performs a series of standard blood tests.&#160; We believe that it is necessary to develop additional series of reagent discs with various tests for use with the Piccolo and VetScan systems.&#160; Historically, we primarily developed reagent discs suitable for the veterinary diagnostic market.&#160; Since 2003, we have received 510(k) clearance from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to begin selling tests, namely high density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL), magnesium assay, phosphorus assay and triglycerides, for the human diagnostic market.&#160; These tests are included in standard tests for which the medical community receives reimbursements from third party payors such as HMOs and Medicare.&#160; We may not be able to successfully manufacture or market these
newly developed reagent discs.&#160; Our failure to meet these challenges will materially adversely affect our operating results and financial condition.</font></p>

<p  align="center"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">29</font></p>
<hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We Rely On Distributors To Sell Our Products; We Rely On Sole Distributor Arrangements In A Number Of Countries</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We distribute our products primarily through distributors.&#160; As a result, we are dependent upon these distributors to sell our products and to assist us in promoting and creating a demand for our products.&#160; We have a number of distributors in the United States who distribute our VetScan products.&#160; Two distributors, DVM Resources and Vedco, Inc., accounted for 17% and 14% of total revenues for fiscal 2005, and 16% and 27%, respectively, of total revenues for fiscal 2004.&#160; In December 2004, we terminated our relationship with Vedco, Inc., a warehousing cooperative for member distributors who sold Abaxis products to their respective customers, as part of the realignment of our distribution channel.&#160; During the third and fourth quarters of fiscal 2005, we worked with other U.S. based regional and national distributors, which included American Veterinary Supply Corp., DVM Resources,
Henry Schein, IVESCO, TradeWinds Trading Company and Western Medical Supply, to expand their sales and services to support the customers currently served by other Vedco distributors.&#160; In the third quarter of fiscal 2005, we negotiated direct distributor agreements with Vedco members Merritt Veterinary Supply and Miller Veterinary Supply.&#160; We believe that our future growth depends, in part, on the efforts of these distributors. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;If one of our distributors were to stop selling our products, we may not be able to replace such lost revenue.&#160; We operate on a purchase order basis with the distributors and the distributors are under no contractual obligation to continue carrying our products.&#160; Further, many of our distributors may carry our competitors&#146; products, and may promote our competitors&#146; products over our own products.&#160; Finally, we do not have at this time distribution partners in the United States who distribute our products for the human medical market.&#160; Internationally, we have a few distributors for our products in both the human and veterinary diagnostic markets, which includes one distributor in Japan who is in the process of obtaining the required approvals for sales of Abaxis products in the respective countries.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We currently have distributors for our products in the following countries:&#160; Australia, Austria, Bahrain, Belgium, Canada, France, Germany, Hong Kong, Ireland, Israel, Italy, Japan, Korea, Kuwait, Mexico, New Zealand, Norway, Portugal, Russia, South Africa, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, United Arab Emirates, the United Kingdom and the United States.&#160; Our distributor in each of these countries is responsible for obtaining the necessary approvals to sell our products.&#160; These distributors may not be successful in obtaining proper approvals for our products in their respective countries, and they may not be successful in marketing our products.&#160; We plan to continue to enter into additional distributor relationships to expand our international distribution base and solidify our international presence.&#160; However, we may not be successful in entering into additional distributor
relationships.&#160; Our distributors may terminate their relationship with us at any time.&#160; Historically, we have experienced a high degree of turnover among our international distributors.&#160; This high degree of turnover makes it difficult for us to establish a steady distribution network overseas.&#160; Consequently, we may not be successful in marketing our Piccolo and VetScan DXS products internationally.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We Depend On Sole Suppliers For Several Key Components To Our Products, Many of Whom We Have Not Entered Into Contractual Relationships With</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We use several key components that are currently available from limited or sole sources as discussed below:</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

  <p>

Brewer &amp; Co. and Nypro Oregon, Inc., currently make the molded plastic   discs which, when loaded with reagents and welded together, form our reagent   disc products.&#160; We believe that only a   few manufacturers are capable of producing these discs to the narrow   tolerances that we require; to date, we have only qualified these two   manufacturers, with Nypro Oregon, Inc. being qualified at two separate   facilities, to manufacture the molded plastic discs.</font></p>  </td>

<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">30</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>

<br>

  <td width="95%" valign="top">

 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For our hematology instruments purchased from Diatron, we are subject to minimum purchase requirements through fiscal 2009.&#160; We operate on a purchase order basis with all of the suppliers of our molded plastic reagent discs, reagent chemicals and blood analyzer components and thus these suppliers are under no contractual obligation to supply us with their products or to do so at specified prices.&#160; Although we believe that there are potential alternate suppliers available for these critical components, to date we have not qualified additional vendors beyond those referenced above. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because we are dependent on a limited number of suppliers and manufacturers for critical components to our products, we are particularly susceptible to any interruption in the supply of these products or the viability of our assembly arrangements.&#160; The loss of any one of these suppliers or a disruption in our manufacturing arrangements could materially adversely affect our business and financial condition. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We Compete With Larger, Better Established Entities Such As Hospitals And Commercial Laboratories</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</b>Blood analysis is a well established field in which there are a number of competitors that have substantially greater financial resources and larger, more established marketing, sales and service organizations than we do.&#160; We compete with the following organizations:</font></p>

<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="2%" valign="top">
  <p>

  <td width="95%" valign="top">

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">commercial clinical laboratories;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We May Not Be Able To Compete With These Organizations Or Their Products Or With Future Organizations Or Future Products</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Historically, hospitals and commercial laboratories perform the most human diagnostic testing, and commercial laboratories perform the most veterinary medical testing.&#160; We have identified five principal factors that customers typically use to evaluate our products and those of our competitors.&#160; These factors are: </font></p>

<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="2%" valign="top">
  <p>

  <p>

 </tr>
 <tr>

  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
